title: On the Metric Dimension of $K_a \times K_b \times K_c$
abstract:
In this work we determine the metric dimension of $ K_a \times K_b \times
K_c$ for all $a,b,c\in \mathbb N$ with $ a \le b \le c $ as follows. For
$3a<b+c$ and $2b \le c$, this value is $c-1$, for $3a<b+c$ and $2b > c$, it is
$\left \lfloor \frac{2}{3}(b+c-1) \right \rfloor$, and for $3a=b+c$, it is
$\left \lfloor \frac{a+b+c}{2} \right \rfloor -1 $. The only open case is
$3a>b+c$, where two values are possible, namely $\left \lfloor \frac{a+b+c}{2}
\right \rfloor -1 $ and $\left \lfloor \frac{a+b+c}{2} \right \rfloor $. This
result extends previous results of C\'acere et al., who computed the metric
dimension of $ K_a \times K_b$, and of Drewes and J\"ager, who computed the
metric dimension of $ K_a \times K_a \times K_a$.
  We prove our result by introducing and analyzing a new variant of Static
Black-Peg Mastermind, in which each peg has its own permitted set of colors.
For all cases, we present strategies which we prove to be both feasible and
optimal. Our main result follows, as the number of questions of these
strategies is equal to the metric dimension of $K_a \times K_b \times K_c$.
